item.title: Terrible Day of the Big Gundown
item.description: Terrible Day of the Big Gundown is a 1971 Italian Spaghetti Western film directed by Sergio Garrone.

item.title: Ace High
item.description: Ace High is a 1968 Italian Spaghetti Western film directed and written by Giuseppe Colizzi and starring Terence Hill, Bud Spencer and Eli Wallach. The film is the second in a trilogy started with God Forgives... I Don't! and ended with Boot Hill.

item.title: Man of the East
item.description: Man of the East is a 1972 Italian spaghetti western film directed by Enzo Barboni starring Terence Hill.

item.title: Vengeance Is a Dish Served Cold
item.description: Vengeance Is a Dish Served Cold, also known as Death's Dealer, is a 1971 Italian Western film directed by Pasquale Squitieri and starring Klaus Kinski.

item.title: They Call Me Trinity
item.description: They Call Me Trinity is a 1970 Italian Spaghetti Western comedy film written and directed by Enzo Barboni and produced by Italo Zingarelli. The film stars Terence Hill and Bud Spencer as two brothers, Trinity and Bambino, who help defend a Mormon settlement from Mexican bandits and the henchman of the land-grabbing Major Harriman. It was filmed on location in Lazio, Italy, with financial backing from West Film.

item.title: A Man Called Sledge
item.description: A Man Called Sledge is a 1970 Italian spaghetti western film starring James Garner in an extremely offbeat role as a grimly evil thief, and featuring Dennis Weaver, Claude Akins and Wayde Preston. The film was written by Vic Morrow and Frank Kowalski, and directed by Morrow in Techniscope.

item.title: Return of Sabata
item.description: Return of Sabata is a 1971 Spaghetti Western film directed by Gianfranco Parolini. The third film in The Sabata Trilogy, it features the return of Lee Van Cleef as the title character, which he had played in the first film, Sabata, but was replaced by Yul Brynner in the second film, Adiós, Sabata, due to a scheduling conflict. Return of Sabata was listed in the 1978 book The Fifty Worst Films of All Time.

item.title: Django – Der Tag der Abrechnung
item.description: Django – Der Tag der Abrechnung ist ein Italowestern von Sergio Garrone aus dem Jahr 1971. Deutschsprachige Erstaufführung war am 29. Juni 1989 im Privatfernsehen.

item.title: Vier für ein Ave Maria
item.description: Vier für ein Ave Maria ist eine Italo-Western-Komödie aus dem Jahr 1968.

item.title: Verflucht, verdammt und Halleluja
item.description: Verflucht, verdammt und Halleluja, in der DDR unter dem Titel Ein Gentleman im Wilden Westen veröffentlicht, ist ein Spielfilm mit Terence Hill, gedreht Anfang der 1970er Jahre unter der Regie von E. B. Clucher alias Enzo Barboni.
